p: Similarly, environment temperature is a critical factor for the ability of Ae. aegypti to transmit DENV, with transmission rates significantly reduced at lower temperatures [ 17, 36]. In addition, lower temperatures are known to reduce vector feeding/biting frequency [ 14] and can significantly reduce vector density/human-vector contact, consequently lowering the risk of DENV transmission by Ae. aegypti mosquitoes in an area [ 37]. This may explain the lack of dengue outbreaks in Nairobi. However, the temperatures in Mombasa and Kisumu, 27/31°C, and 28/30°C, respectively, are nearly identical. Therefore, temperature cannot explain the lack of dengue outbreaks in Kisumu.
